course_title: Cultural Management: Leadership in Arts Organisations

learning_outcomes.description: Understand and analyse current debates within contemporary museum management practices.
Develop practical skills relating to museum management.
Develop a knowledge base relating to policy and governmental frameworks within which museums and galleries operate.
Undertake research in chosen area of interest or specialization from a museum management perspective.

assessments.task_description:
Using the Discussion Board on the course Blackboard site students post a few sentences (50-75 words) about each of the required readings for each weekly topic from week 1 to week 9. Students should ideally post on the required readings BEFORE the seminar for which they are set.

In your post you should say what you think the key arguments of the reading are. You can add your own opinion about the reading, its style and content.

The purpose of this assessment is to become fluent in critical reading and to learn key theories in museum studies. These readings can also be used to build your essay assessment.

Each reading counts as one post. A minimum of 8 reading posts on this Discussion Board is required to receive full marks for this assessment. If you submit less than 8, you will receive a mark for every post (e.g. 4 posts = 4/20).

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard for this course.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Tutorial on posting to Discussion Boards. Please contact the UQ Library for help with the technical aspects of posting or creating and adding to discussion threads.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 2: Topical essay - choose a topic. 2400 words max
assessments.task_description:
Aim; the aim of this essay is to demonstrate your understanding of the key management concepts introduced in the first part of this course. Your essay is of 2400 words including references. The word count can be 10% over or under this total. In this essay you will discuss the case for museum management using learning from the seminars in the course to date. The format and style is essay. Your essay should have an introduction and a conclusion.

Choose ONE of the following topics:

Discuss and evaluate some of the different kinds of organisation structures museums have today

Use 2 or 3 case studies to support your arguments.


Describe and assess ways of leading change in the management of museum.

Use 2 or 3 case studies to support your arguments.


Discuss the role that fund raising plays in museum management.

Use 2 or 3 case studies to support your arguments.

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard for this course.

assessments.task_description:
Assignment 3; Report on cultural organisation case study.

Project Scenario

You are hired as a consultant to work on a cultural organisation improvement project. Your task, in groups, is to research your chosen cultural organisation, its history, mission, vision, goals and strategies and identify future opportunities for it. Your group will present your project pitch in the final seminar of the course. Each member of the group must speak for an equal amount of time. Practice runs at presenting are recommended. 20% of your marks for this project are for your personal presentation and contribution as part of the group project and presentation. See marking rubric on Blackboard for details.

Each student will develop a written report which will cover the findings of the group. Feel free to expand or draw out elements of the study that you feel are important. Give the report your personal touch. The assessed work should be written in report form and should include references, methodologies and presentation of data and related material. Remember that in this project you are selling your ideas to the museum's board and management.

Your project report should cover the following themes –

• cultural organisation history, mission, vision, strategic and operational

• An examination of the brand and its implementation.

• An overview of the resources your improvement proposal would require and how these resources might be acquired.

• An assessment of the cultural organisation financial status both before and after your proposal is implemented. What are the key benefits for the Museum if it adopts your proposal?

You can choose any kind of cultural institution as your case study. there will be opportunity in class to discuss your choice with your peers and with the course lecturers.

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard for this course.

learning_activities.topic:
Museum marketing, fundraising and PR

This seminar will discuss the important role that marketing, fundraising and PR (Public Relations) plays in a contemporary museum. It will explore how to powerfully engage museum audiences, funders, partners, and stakeholders.

Visit to University of Queensland Art Museum. Guest speakers: Alex Tuite (Engagement and Partnerships) and Tallara Gray (Education and Public Programs), UQAM.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05

It will explore how to powerfully engage museum audiences, funders, partners, and stakeholders. Visit to University of Queensland Art Museum. Guest speakers: Alex Tuite (Engagement and Partnerships) and Tallara Gray (Education and Public Programs), UQAM.

learning_activities.topic:
Leading change

This seminar will explore museum leadership and the role of the Director in managing change. We will discuss the ongoing transition of museums from the “old” to the “new” museology and the need for museums to be in a constant state of change in order to remain relevant to a world where the rate of change is accelerating. 

Visit to Queensland Art Gallery | Gallery of Modern Art. Guest speaker: Simon Elliott, Deputy Director, QAGOMA. 

Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Defining the business of a museum

This seminar will explore the importance of vision and mission in managing a complex organisation. It will introduce strategic planning and the role of the Director in guiding this process. Discussions will focus on how vision, mission, strategy, values and brand can reset an organisation’s compass and explore how this new direction might be implemented. 

Visit to Fryer Library. Guest speaker: Simon Farley, Manager Fryer Library

learning_activities.topic:
Policy, creativity and public value in Cultural Management

One of the key elements in the transformation of museums and other arts organisation in the past decade has been the shift from a collection focus to a visitor focus. This seminar examines new arts sector policy in Australia might promote the now standard industry terms of creativity and public value.

Visit to Queensland Museum. Guest speaker: Jim Thompson, CEO, Queensland Museum network.

Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Partnerships

This seminar will examine the changing dynamics between a museum, or arts organisation, its audience, communities and other stakeholders. Cultural organisations can play a leadership role within its communities when the relationship is based on shared values. These values can facilitate social, cultural and economic benefits for both the museum and its communities. 

Guest speaker: Sarah Thompson, Director, Hervey Bay Regional Gallery (via Zoom).
